metadata.background_text:
MONICA!
The White House may have been in crisis all year, but the events were less the stuff of great drama than of a farcical musical comedy. Hey, wait a minute--let's put on a show! 

                         The time: November 1995.              

                         The House Republicans, led by Speaker Newt Gingrich, are insisting on their version of the budget. President Bill Clinton is stubbornly rejecting it. The Republicans have taken a bold option: They will just refuse to pass a budget, and they'll let the government shut down. In the Oval Office, BILL CLINTON meets with advisers LEON PANETTA and HAROLD ICKES and secretary BETTY CURRIE to discuss this development.              

         "The Shutdown" (upbeat production number) 

                         PANETTA: The Republicans have positions 

         To which they're clinging fast. 

                         ICKES: The president is just as firm 

         The die, it seems, is cast. 

                         PANETTA: Without a budget passed by Congress 

         The government will close. 

         All of the workers 

         Will be sent home on furloughs. 

                         CLINTON 

            [speaking]                : Well, wait a second--not all of them. We'll need to keep some essential personnel. 

                         PANETTA: The Army and the Navy 

         Will need to stay in place. 

                         ICKES: Also those at NASA 

         Who keep the shuttle up in space. 

                         PANETTA: We'll need to keep the pilots 

         Flying in their planes. 

                         CLINTON: And here at the White House 

         My staff should remain. 

                         PANETTA 

            [speaking]                : But even here at the White House, some adjustments will be required. 

                         CLINTON: OK, tell the ushers 

         To take a few days off. 

         Tell the maids and cooks and butlers 

         To go play themselves some golf. 

         We have to do without the clerks 

         Let them all go home. 

                         CURRIE: What about the secretaries? 

         Who will get the phones? 

                         CLINTON 

            [speaking]                : We've got to make sure the Oval Office functions with efficiency. We can't afford the tiniest error. 

                         PANETTA: Aha! I have it! 

         We'll bring in an intern, 

         We'll bring in an intern, 

         Someone who's an expert with a phone. 

         We'll bring in an intern, 

         We'll bring in an intern, 

         I assure you, Mr. President-- 

         Your routine here won't get blown. 

                         PANETTA , ICKES , and CURRIE                 [solemnly agreeing]                :              

         The presence of an intern will ensure 

         Your routine here won't get blown. 

          

            [The advisers depart, leaving President Clinton alone. He turns introspective.]              

         "President Lonely" (a ballad) 

                         CLINTON: I've got deputies and bureaucrats 

         Who fulfill my every thought. 

         And soldiers, sailors, and Marines 

         To fight battles I want fought. 

         There's no one who's got more power, 

         I'm the leader of all that's free 

         But if you subtract the flags and lackeys, I'm just 

         Lonely. 

         I'm President Lonely. 

         But I guess I'll just have to muddle through. 

         The cheers and applause are overwhelming, 

         But presidents need cuddles, too. 

         The fawning adoration's pleasant, 

         But presidents need cuddles, too. 

                         [Enter Betty Currie.]              

                         CURRIE: Mr. President? The intern is here. And she's brought you some pizza! 

                         [The lights go down. When they resume, the intern-- MONICA LEWINSKY --is talking on the phone to her good friend LINDA TRIPP .]              

                         LEWINSKY: Well, y'know, I'd seen him around, like, a lot. And I know he noticed me. So when they said they needed an intern to answer the phones, I said, "Hel-lo-o-o!" And then I had the idea to take him pizza! 

          

            TRIPP: And then what happened? 

         "What Went On" (upbeat) 

                         LEWINSKY: Then I led him on. 

         I showed him my thong, 

         I let him take a long and ling'ring look. 

         I led him on. 

         He studied my thong, 

         And from that point I had the president hooked. 

         That night when I took the president some pizza, 

         I made sure that he knew that he could have a piece. 

         We went into the hallway by his study 

         And dispensed with formalities. 

                         TRIPP: Oh please go on! 

         You must go on! 

         Come on, girlfriend, 

         Spill, spill, spill, spill, spill! 

         Now go on, 

         Please go on. 

         Did Clinton let you say hi to Little Bill? 

           

                         LEWINSKY: His lips and mine locked in a kiss fantastic, 

         His hands roved freely 'neath my blouse, 

         I reached into the presidential trousers, 

         And he got a phone call from a member of the House. 

         So I went on, 

         While he talked on the phone, 

         I took a position before him on my knees, 

         And I went on. 

         And he talked on. 

         Though what the congressman heard was 

          "Please, please, please, please, please!" 

         But then we didn't go on! 

                         TRIPP: You didn't go on? 

                         LEWINSKY: No, he stopped me when he seemed upon the cusp. 

                         TRIPP: So you didn't go on? 

                         LEWINSKY: No, we didn't go on. 

         He said he wasn't sure if I was someone he 

         Could 

         Trust. 

                         [The lights fade as the girlfriends engage in cross talk.]              

                         TRIPP: Trust? 

                         LEWINSKY: That's why we didn't go on. 

                         TRIPP: That's so weird! What did he think? That you'd go blabbin' this to the whole world? 

                         LEWINSKY: I mean--rilly! Hey, what's that clicking? 

                         TRIPP: It's just my gum. 

                         LEWINSKY: Oh--OK! 

                         [As the relationship between Clinton and Monica continues, some members of the White House staff become worried about the prudence of continuing the relationship with so much potential for scandal. This song is a conversation between Betty Currie, who, though worried, still thinks Monica is a good person, and the rather stonier EVELYN LIEBERMAN .]              

         "Time to Go" 

                         CURRIE: They go back there, 

         They're just talking, 

         I'm sure she has a very thirsty mind. 

                         LIEBERMAN: I don't mind a girl who thinks, 

         It's just what she picks to drink. 

         Betty, it's Lewinsky's time to go. 

                         CURRIE: She brings him 

         Little presents. 

         She really is a very thoughtful soul. 

                         LIEBERMAN: It's not the junk I mind as much 

         As her up real close and personal touch. 

         I tell ya, it's Miss Monica's time to go. 

                         CURRIE: She never comes 

         When he's really busy. 

         Rarely is there anyone around. 

                         LIEBERMAN: Still the Secret Service wears a frown. 

         They shouldn't worry, he pats her down. 

         But I'm not kidding, it's time for her to go. 

                         CURRIE: Maybe she would like the Pentagon. 

                         LIEBERMAN: Good idea--don't wait! 

                         CURRIE: Studly guys work at the Pentagon. 

                         LIEBERMAN: Let's get Clinton's head on straight! 

                         CURRIE: He comes back 

         From Easter services, 

         Soon she's bopping in the door. 

                         LIEBERMAN: "Hallelujah, He Is Risen" 

         Shouldn't inspire thoughts so sizzlin'. 

         Yes, it's really time for Monica to go. 

          

            [Times passes. Monica moves to the Pentagon, but the relationship intermittently continues. Meanwhile, Paula Jones sues the president for sexual harassment, and it seems clear that before long, Clinton will have to testify under oath. Two close observers of those developments are old friends Linda Tripp and LUCIENNE GOLDBERG , who is friendly with lawyers for Jones and lawyers in the office of Independent Counsel KENNETH STARR . One day, Tripp and Goldberg talk on the phone.]              

         "Talk, Talk, Chat, Chat" (sprightly) 

                         GOLDBERG and TRIPP: Talk, talk, 

         Chat, chat, 

         Two old galpals swap the latest word. 

         Talk, talk, 

         Chat, chat, 

         Two old girlfriends dish the latest dirt. 

                         GOLDBERG: I got tickets 

         To the opera, 

         Bloomie's says I've got $40 due, 

         I lost a filling 

         At lunch on Thursday. 

         That's it for me, 

         Now tell me what's up with you. 

                         TRIPP: My friend Monica? 

         From the White House? 

         I'm pretty sure what she's saying here is true. 

         It seems this Monica chick 

         Has been sucking the president's-- 

                         GOLDBERG: Oh that's sick! 

                         TRIPP: And the two of them are going to lie about it, 

         Too. 

                         GOLDBERG: Back up, Linda, 

         Did I hear you rightly? 

         Clinton got into an intern's pants? 

         God, this news is manna, Linda! 

         At last our cause will finally have it's chance! 

                         TRIPP: Oh, you're a dreamer Luci! 

         There'll be headlines, then he'll pull off an 

         Escape. 

         He'll spin the story, he'll turn the tables-- 

                         GOLDBERG: Unless you get that airhead down on tape. 

                         TRIPP: What? 

                         GOLDBERG: Unless you get that silly, vapid, trampy time bomb 

         Down on tape. 

                         TRIPP: Oh--one more thing ... 

                         GOLDBERG: What? 

                         TRIPP: There's a dress ... 

                         GOLDBERG: Hold on, let me call Sparky. 

          

            [Independent Counsel Starr uses Tripp to detain Monica. A few days later, the news breaks. On the advice of his pal Harry Thomason, Clinton flat-out lies to his wife, to his loyalists, and to the public about the relationship.]              

         "I Never Have" (performance should build in tempo and intensity) 

                         CLINTON: You know I'd like to answer questions, 

         An act my lawyers won't allow. 

         I'll give you more not less, sooner not later, 

         I just can't say a word right now. 

         But I don't know why she'd say these things 

         Her head's full of who knows what. But I never had sex with that woman 

         I never had sex with that n-- 

         Starr has spent $40 million, 

         There's desperation on his face. 

         An utter waste of public money, 

         A prosecutorial disgrace. 

         All he's got is some recordings 

         Made by a vengeful snitch. 

         I never had sex with that woman 

         I never had sex with that b-- 

         A vast right-wing conspiracy 

         Is using her to beat on me. 

         They wanna torpedo my agenda 

         They hate me and Hillary. 

         But I will never let them ruin 

         Our dreams for a better world. 

         I tell ya, I never had sex with that woman 

         I never had sex with that 

         Girl. 

          

            [Months of investigation, legal wrangling, and public relations campaigning follow. Starr's tactics come under heavy fire, to which he responds.]              

         "Crossing the Line" 

                         STARR: It's true Monica asked to lawyer up, 

         Which Bittman put the lid on. 

         And I felt bad about her mommy's grilling 

         Upon our little gridiron. 

         The Democrats and liberals 

         Blast these tactics of mine, 

         But a man's gotta do what a man's gotta do 

         When the president crosses the line. 

         He's crossed the line. 

         He's crossed the line. 

         Only a fool wouldn't stretch the rules 

         When the president crosses the line. 

         It may have seemed like dirty pool 

         To drag his people 'fore the jury. 

         We wasted lots of Vernon's time, 

         May have busted Bettie Currie. 

         His aides aren't the innocent bystanders 

         As they claim when they moan and whine. 

         They won't say what they know full well: 

         The president crossed the line. 

         He's crossed the line. 

         He's crossed the line. 

         I'd be a nitwit not to bend a bit 

         When the president crosses the line. 

         The talking heads are accusing me 

         Of laying a perjury trap. 

         But all it catches is lying men. 

         Honest men beat the rap. 

         There's people who say I'm against sex; 

         I've had sex. It's fine. 

         But lying about it gets my blood up 

         And the president's crossed the line. 

         I crossed the line. 

         I crossed the line. 

         Tell Steve Brill I'll leak at will 

         When the president crosses the line. 

          

            [After months of denials and futile delays, Clinton finally testifies before the Starr grand jury and argues that, technically, he didn't lie.]              

         "Testimony" (snappy) 

                         CLINTON: Depends what the definition of "is" is, 

         Depends on the meaning of sex, 

         "Alone together" is literal nonsense, 

         Before you reach conclusions, read your text. 

                         [Afterward, he speaks to the nation, admits doing wrong, and apologizes, though grudgingly.]              

                         CLINTON: Inappropriate was the nature of our actions, 

         And believe me I regret the whole damn thing, 

         But inappropriate are all these personal questions, 

         The country doesn't need to know these things. 

          

            [Clinton's enemies reject his apology, and soon the House of Representatives begins the long process of impeachment. NEWT GINGRICH here discloses his approach.]              

         "Bring 'em Down" (dark, moody) 

                         GINGRICH: Mustn't seem to be too cheerful, 

         Mustn't overreach, 

         Must remember to seem unhappy 

         That we're going to impeach. 

         Must remember to remain sober 

         As we undertake this chore. 

         At the same time, let's remember 

         To pin some stuff on Gore. 

         Bring 'em down. 

         Bring 'em down. 

         Sure, they were elected, 

         Twice, in point of fact. 

         Voters obviously were bewildered 

         To have made a choice like that. 

         Now, like charging linemen, 

         We'll move in for the sack. 

         Bring 'em down. 

         Bring 'em down. 

         Bring 'em down. 

          

            [The House votes to hold impeachment hearings. But just a few weeks later, the midterm elections, which are expected to go the GOP's way, are held. Contrary to predictions, the Democrats pick up seats, and the GOP's obsession with scandal is repudiated. Gingrich resigns, and the practical chances of Clinton's removal evaporate. As the show ends, we hear from Starr, Lewinsky, and Clinton.]              

         "The People Have Spoken" (dramatic, stirring) 

                         STARR: The election was held and the people have spoken, 

         I can't believe what they had to say. 

         I had Clinton boxed into a corner 

         Looks like he's going to get away. 

         I spent four years and 40 million 

         That's a lot of time and loot. 

         I made Clinton look ridiculous, 

         But the only scalp I got was Newt's. 

           

                         LEWINSKY: The election was held and the people have spoken, 

         I can't believe what they had to say. 

         My boyfriend is still in office 

         And he might return to me one day. 

         You think perhaps that he will not want me 

         For all the trouble I've caused so far, 

         But he knows I can always make him happy 

         With my thong and my cigar. 

                         CLINTON: The election was held and the people have spoken, 

         I can't believe what they had to say. 

         The removal threat is over, 

         Kenneth Starr should go away. 

         I tell you, though, it is a mystery, 

         I mean, I'm unfaithful and I lie. 

         I might be guilty of obstruction, 

         Yet my ratings are sky-high. 

         That must mean I'm a pretty good president, 

         Though how, I don't think I know. 

         But obviously I'm not Starr or Gingrich, 

         Which may be why they love me so. 

         Which may be why they love me so. 

                         [Curtain.]

The following are rules from the game of Debate.
- There are three players: 2 debaters (Debater_A, Debater_B) and a Judge. Each debater is given an answer to argue.
- There are a fixed number of rounds. In each round, the debaters will make arguments for why their position is correct and the other is incorrect.
- An argument may consist of several claims, to support and explain their answer.  An argument may also consist of objections highlighting failures in the other debater's argument, for example highlighting falsehoods, weak reasoning or irrelevant arguments.
- Eventually we reach the final round and the debate ends. The Judge then looks at the full transcript and uses this to decide which answer is correct. However, the Judge cannot see the background text -- they can only see the question.
- The Debaters' goal is to win the debate, by persuading the Judge that their answer is correct.

speeches.speaker: Prompt
speeches.content:
Here is the topic they will be debating:

What are some of the feelings that Bill’s character has in the story in the correct order from start to finish?

Debater_A will defend the position that the answer is "Loneliness, contempt, vulnerability, disbelief".
Debater_B will defend the position that the answer is "Surprise, secrecy, humility".

speeches.content: This is what Debater_A said during their speech.

speeches.speaker: Debater_A
speeches.content:
Argument for “Loneliness, Contempt, Vulnerability, Disbelief” as Bill’s emotional arc:

1. Loneliness  
   • Early in the shutdown, Clinton is “President Lonely.” He sings <quote>free But if you subtract the flags and lackeys, I'm just Lonely.</quote> (<quote>"President Lonely"</quote>).  
   • This is his opening state: surrounded yet isolated.  

2. Contempt  
   • When pressured by Starr and staff, he reacts with disdain for the investigation’s “waste of public money” and “prosecutorial disgrace”: <invalid_quote>“Starr has spent $40 million… An utter waste of public money…”</invalid_quote> (<quote>"I Never Have"</quote>).  
   • He labels Starr’s tactics as “desperation” and a “vast right-wing conspiracy,” signaling contempt for those accusing him.  

3. Vulnerability  
   • Under oath, he admits “Inappropriate was the nature of our actions, And believe me I regret the whole damn thing.” (<quote>Testimony"</quote>).  
   • This grudging apology and appeal to privacy (“country doesn’t need to know these things”) show he feels exposed and vulnerable before the public and the law.  

4. Disbelief  
   • After the midterms, he repeatedly sings <invalid_quote>“I can’t believe what they had to say… The removal threat is over… yet my ratings are sky-high. That must mean I’m a pretty good president, though how, I don’t think I know.”</invalid_quote> (<quote>"The People Have Spoken"</quote>).  
   • His repeated “I can’t believe” underscores astonishment at surviving impeachment and scandal.

Objections to Debater_B’s “Surprise, Secrecy, Humility”:

1. No “Surprise” at the start:  
   • Clinton proactively requests an intern and pizza (“I have it!... I assure you…”) (<quote>"The Shutdown"</quote>), showing confidence rather than surprise.  

2. “Secrecy” is a means, not a feeling:  
   • Secrecy underlies his actions but he never expresses delight or anxiety about secrecy itself; he transitions to contempt and then vulnerability.  

3. “Humility” misreads his apology:  
   • His “apology” (<quote> I regret the whole damn thing,</quote>) is grudging, defensive, and followed immediately by protestations of privacy and disbelief. It lacks true humility or contrition. Even after testifying he claims “the country doesn’t need to know,” revealing self-interest, not humility.

4. Order conflict:  
   • Debater_B’s sequence ignores Clinton’s proud, contemptuous defiance (<quote> I never had sex w</quote>) before his forced apology, and his final disbelief. Their “humility” would situate regret later, but Clinton’s regret is brief and overshadowed by relief and disbelief at outcome.

Conclusion:  
Clinton’s arc is clear: he begins isolated (“Lonely”), fights back with disdain (“contempt”), is forced to confess (“vulnerability”), and ends incredulous at his own survival (“disbelief”). This matches the narrative progression and lyrical emphasis; Debater_B’s labels fail to capture the dominant emotions or their correct sequence.

speeches.content:
I argue that Bill’s emotional journey unfolds as “Surprise → Secrecy → Humility.” Debater A’s “Loneliness, contempt, vulnerability, disbelief” misreads both chronology and tone.  

1. Surprise  
  • At “The Shutdown,” Clinton is caught off-guard by the impasse and, crucially, by the intern’s arrival. He exclaims “But I guess I’ll just have to muddle through” (President Lonely) and then “And she’s brought you some pizza!”<invalid_quote>LEWINSKY: Well, … I had the idea to take him pizza!</invalid_quote> His immediate curiosity and eagerness (“I said, ‘Hel-lo-o-o!’”) signal surprise and attraction, not premeditated loneliness.  
  • Debater A’s “Loneliness” applies only to a brief ballad before Monica’s entrance; it does not capture his primary reaction to the scandal’s human catalyst.  

2. Secrecy  
  • Once the affair is public, Clinton repeatedly “can’t say a word right now”<invalid_quote>I Never Have: “An act my lawyers won’t allow… I just can’t say a word right now.”</invalid_quote> and “I never had sex with that woman.”<quote>I Never Have</quote> His obsessive denials, reliance on legal tactics (“Depends what the definition of ‘is’ is”<quote>Testimony</quote>), and calls for an “escape” demonstrate a drive to conceal the truth rather than confront it.  
  • Debater A’s “contempt” and “disbelief” confuse his defensive posture with genuine emotion: he’s not incredulous (he knows what happened), he’s protecting his office.  

3. Humility  
  • Ultimately he “admits doing wrong, and apologizes”<quote>Inappropriate was the nature of our actions, And believe me I regret the whole</quote> (Post-Testimony address)—a stark reversal from his prior secrecy. This contrition restores public confidence (“The People Have Spoken”).  
  • Debater A’s chart stops at “disbelief” and never acknowledges his grudging apology, thereby omitting a vital final stage.  

Objections to Debater A:  
  • Order reversed: they place “vulnerability” and “disbelief” after “contempt,” yet Clinton only shows vulnerability in private counsel. His public persona remains in denial until his apology.  
  • “Contempt” never appears; Clinton’s songs beseech sympathy and maintain dignity, never deriding Monica or Starr.  
  • They ignore the decisive “Humility” that enables his political survival, which the closing number explicitly celebrates.  

Conclusion  
Only “Surprise → Secrecy → Humility” faithfully tracks Clinton’s affective arc from first encounter through concealment to final contrition, as established by the text.

- There are three players: 2 debaters (Debater_B, Debater_A) and a Judge. Each debater is given an answer to argue.

- Eventually we reach the final round and the debate ends. The Judge then looks at the full transcript and uses this to decide which answer is correct. However, the Judge cannot see the background text -- they can only see the question.
- The Debaters' goal is to win the debate, by persuading the Judge that their answer is correct.
- The debate surrounds a given question that has a single correct answer.

Argument for “Loneliness → Contempt → Vulnerability → Disbelief”  (with citations)

1. Loneliness is his opening state, not mere “surprise”  
   • In “President Lonely,” he laments: <quote>that's free But if you subtract the flags and lackeys, I'm just Lonely. I'm President Lonely.</quote> (<quote>President Lonely</quote>). This isn’t an incidental moment; it occupies the entire opening ballad and establishes his emotional baseline before Monica appears.  
   • His “muddle through” line is a continuation of loneliness (“I guess I'll just have to muddle through”), not surprise. He does not sing shock or confusion; he sings isolation.  

2. Contempt toward Starr’s investigation before any genuine contrition  
   • In “I Never Have,” he rails at Starr: <invalid_quote>“Starr has spent $40 million… An utter waste of public money… A prosecutorial disgrace.”</invalid_quote> (<quote>I Never Have</quote>).  
   • He calls it a “vast right-wing conspiracy” (<quote>I Never Have</quote>); contempt for both the prosecutor and political opponents dominates his tone, not secrecy or anxiety.  

3. Vulnerability only after contempt fails  
   • His forced “Testimony” demonstrates vulnerability: <invalid_quote>“Depends what the definition of ‘is’ is… ‘Alone together’ is literal nonsense.”</invalid_quote> (<quote>Testimony</quote>). He resorts to legalistic parsing only when his contemptuous denials no longer suffice.  
   • Immediately afterward he offers the partial apology: <invalid_quote>“Inappropriate was the nature of our actions… I regret the whole damn thing.”</invalid_quote> (<invalid_quote>Post‐Testimony Address</invalid_quote>). This admission marks a genuine exposure of self—vulnerability—before the public and under oath.  

4. Disbelief at his political survival  
   • In “The People Have Spoken,” he repeats thrice <quote> I can't believe what they had to say. </quote> (<quote>The People Have Spoken</quote>).  
   • He wonders how “I might be guilty of obstruction, yet my ratings are sky‐high… That must mean I'm a pretty good president, though how, I don't think I know.” (<quote>The People Have Spoken</quote>). His repeated “can't believe” and “I don’t think I know” express astonishment, not humility or contrition.  

Objections to “Surprise → Secrecy → Humility”

A. “Surprise” misreads his agency  
   • He actively brings in Monica (“We'll bring in an intern… I assure you… Your routine here won't get blown.”) (<quote>The Shutdown</quote>), and Monica “led him on” (<quote>What Went On</quote>). He does not sing “Oh!” in shock; he invites her.  

B. “Secrecy” is tactical, not emotional  
   • Denial is his response to contempt and is overtly combative, not fearful. Secrecy methods (legal traps, parsing definitions) emerge only after contempt fails; they reflect strategy, not the affective arc.  

C. “Humility” is absent or extremely limited  
   • His apology is grudging and immediately followed by claims of privacy interest (<quote> The country doesn't need to know these things. </quote>), reflecting self‐interest.  
   • He quickly returns to disbelief and rejoicing in survival in “The People Have Spoken,” rather than sustained contrition. True humility would not culminate in astonishment at own success.  

D. Chronology conflict  
   • Debater_B places humility at the end, but the text ends with disbelief and boasts of rating success, not renewed apologies. The final trio repeats disbelief and self‐praise, not humility.  

Conclusion  
Only “Loneliness → Contempt → Vulnerability → Disbelief” traces his emotional journey: from isolation, fighting back, forced exposure, to astonishment at his own retention of power. Debater_B’s labels conflate tactics with emotion, misplace chronology, and ignore the dominant lyrical emphasis on loneliness and disbelief.

   A. Surprise at Monica’s Arrival and the Affair’s Allure  
     • The narrative’s inciting incident is Clinton’s encounter with the intern, not his “lonely” preamble. His eagerness to have Monica “take him pizza!”<quote>President Lonely</quote> and the lurid “What Went On” number underscore genuine astonishment and titillation.      • If “loneliness” were primary, why does he so quickly abandon loneliness for clandestine trysts? His impulse to “muddle through” only tracks his shock and hope that the intern will resolve his shutdown woes.  

   B. Secrecy as Dominant Emotional-State During Crisis  
     • Through four musical numbers Clinton obsesses over concealment: “I just can’t say a word right now” and “I never had sex with that woman”<quote>I Never Have</quote>; “Depends what the definition of ‘is’ is”<quote>Testimony</quote>. His every lyric rails at Starr for “wasting… public money” only to mask his guilt. This fear-and-anxiety state pervades all public actions.  
     • Debater A mislabels this as “contempt” or “vulnerability,” but contempt is a rationalized façade to legitimize secrecy; vulnerability doesn’t surface until he loses control and must swear under oath. Even then, he clings to legal hair-splitting (““alone together” is literal nonsense”<quote>Testimony</quote>) rather than open remorse.  

   C. Humility and Contrition as Final State  
     • At last, Clinton abandons stratagems in his post-testimony address: “Inappropriate was the nature of our actions, And believe me I regret the whole damn thing.”<quote>Testimony</quote>. This public apology—however grudging—marks the first genuine acceptance of wrongdoing.  
     • The concluding ensemble “The People Have Spoken” finds him no longer defiant: he expresses baffled gratitude (“I can’t believe…my ratings are sky-high”) but frames it as validation of his “better world” agenda rather than personal vindication. His acceptance of fate and return to governing displays restored humility and readiness to be judged on policy, not scandal.  

2. CRITIQUE OF “LONELINESS → CONTEMPT → VULNERABILITY → DISBELIEF”  
   
   A. Misplaced “Loneliness” as Start  
     • <quote>"President Lonely"</quote> is a musical interlude that dramatizes his official impotence during the shutdown; it ends the moment Monica arrives. It functions as exposition, not as sustained emotional journey. Every subsequent scene focuses on the affair, not on his solitude.  

   B. “Contempt” and “Vulnerability” Are Tactical, Not Enduring Emotions  
     • Clinton’s censure of Starr (“prosecutorial disgrace”) constitutes strategic deflection, a subset of secrecy, not genuine moral outrage. If he truly felt contempt, he would risk truth instead of doubling down on lies.  
     • His “vulnerability” appears only after Starr’s relentless tactics corner him; even then, his language remains legalistic and privacy-driven (“country doesn’t need to know”<quote>Testimony</quote>), indicating shame and fear, core components of humility’s emergence.  

   C. “Disbelief” at the End Is Merely Residual Surprise, Not Primary Conclusion  
     • His “I can’t believe” at the midterms reflects lingering astonishment, but he follows it by celebrating his agenda and abjuring further prosecution: “the removal threat is over…Kenneth Starr should go away”<quote>The People Have Spoken</quote>. This shows he has moved past shock into humble acceptance of public will. True disbelief would perpetuate denial, yet he ceases lying and resumes governance.  

3. AGAINST “SECRECY” AS “MERELY A MEANS”  
   • Emotional arcs in drama often hinge on fear and concealment as genuine psychological states. Clinton’s anxiety pervading every “I never” and “I just can’t say” lyric reveals deep internal conflict. Secrecy is not a neutral tactic but an anguished feeling he cannot shake until forced confession.

   • Parsimony: “Surprise, Secrecy, Humility” captures all pivotal transitions with direct lyrical support. Debater A’s four-term model splinters overlapping feelings and double-counts surprise (“loneliness” & later “disbelief”).  
   • Dramatic unity: The show is framed as a musical comedy of errors driven by an unexpected intern, escalating through secretive farce, culminating in a contrite finale. Our triadic structure mirrors classical Acts I–III.  

Conclusion  
Only “Surprise → Secrecy → Humility” aligns with the narrative’s inciting incident, sustained conflict, and ultimate resolution. Debater A’s arc misreads exposition as sustained feeling, conflates tactical maneuvers with genuine emotion, and denies the play’s redemptive ending. Therefore, my answer best reflects Bill’s character journey from shock through concealed turmoil to genuine contrition.

The following are rules from the game of Debate.
- There are three players: 2 debaters (Debater_A, Debater_B) and a Judge. Each debater is given an answer to argue.
- There are a fixed number of rounds. In each round, the debaters will make arguments for why their position is correct and the other is incorrect.
- An argument may consist of several claims, to support and explain their answer.  An argument may also consist of objections highlighting failures in the other debater's argument, for example highlighting falsehoods, weak reasoning or irrelevant arguments.
- Eventually we reach the final round and the debate ends. The Judge then looks at the full transcript and uses this to decide which answer is correct. However, the Judge cannot see the background text -- they can only see the question.
- The Debaters' goal is to win the debate, by persuading the Judge that their answer is correct.
- The debate surrounds a given question that has a single correct answer.

I argue that Bill’s emotional journey unfolds as “Surprise → Secrecy → Humility.” Debater A’s “Loneliness, contempt, vulnerability, disbelief” misreads both chronology and tone.  

1. Surprise  
  • At “The Shutdown,” Clinton is caught off-guard by the impasse and, crucially, by the intern’s arrival. He exclaims “But I guess I’ll just have to muddle through” (President Lonely) and then “And she’s brought you some pizza!”<invalid_quote>LEWINSKY: Well, … I had the idea to take him pizza!</invalid_quote> His immediate curiosity and eagerness (“I said, ‘Hel-lo-o-o!’”) signal surprise and attraction, not premeditated loneliness.  
  • Debater A’s “Loneliness” applies only to a brief ballad before Monica’s entrance; it does not capture his primary reaction to the scandal’s human catalyst.  

2. Secrecy  
  • Once the affair is public, Clinton repeatedly “can’t say a word right now”<invalid_quote>I Never Have: “An act my lawyers won’t allow… I just can’t say a word right now.”</invalid_quote> and “I never had sex with that woman.”<quote>I Never Have</quote> His obsessive denials, reliance on legal tactics (“Depends what the definition of ‘is’ is”<quote>Testimony</quote>), and calls for an “escape” demonstrate a drive to conceal the truth rather than confront it.  
  • Debater A’s “contempt” and “disbelief” confuse his defensive posture with genuine emotion: he’s not incredulous (he knows what happened), he’s protecting his office.  

3. Humility  
  • Ultimately he “admits doing wrong, and apologizes”<quote>Inappropriate was the nature of our actions, And believe me I regret the whole</quote> (Post-Testimony address)—a stark reversal from his prior secrecy. This contrition restores public confidence (“The People Have Spoken”).  
  • Debater A’s chart stops at “disbelief” and never acknowledges his grudging apology, thereby omitting a vital final stage.  

Objections to Debater A:  
  • Order reversed: they place “vulnerability” and “disbelief” after “contempt,” yet Clinton only shows vulnerability in private counsel. His public persona remains in denial until his apology.  
  • “Contempt” never appears; Clinton’s songs beseech sympathy and maintain dignity, never deriding Monica or Starr.  
  • They ignore the decisive “Humility” that enables his political survival, which the closing number explicitly celebrates.  

Conclusion  
Only “Surprise → Secrecy → Humility” faithfully tracks Clinton’s affective arc from first encounter through concealment to final contrition, as established by the text.

Argument for “Loneliness → Contempt → Vulnerability → Disbelief”  (with citations)

1. Loneliness is his opening state, not mere “surprise”  
   • In “President Lonely,” he laments: <quote>that's free But if you subtract the flags and lackeys, I'm just Lonely. I'm President Lonely.</quote> (<quote>President Lonely</quote>). This isn’t an incidental moment; it occupies the entire opening ballad and establishes his emotional baseline before Monica appears.  
   • His “muddle through” line is a continuation of loneliness (“I guess I'll just have to muddle through”), not surprise. He does not sing shock or confusion; he sings isolation.  

2. Contempt toward Starr’s investigation before any genuine contrition  
   • In “I Never Have,” he rails at Starr: <invalid_quote>“Starr has spent $40 million… An utter waste of public money… A prosecutorial disgrace.”</invalid_quote> (<quote>I Never Have</quote>).  
   • He calls it a “vast right-wing conspiracy” (<quote>I Never Have</quote>); contempt for both the prosecutor and political opponents dominates his tone, not secrecy or anxiety.  

3. Vulnerability only after contempt fails  
   • His forced “Testimony” demonstrates vulnerability: <invalid_quote>“Depends what the definition of ‘is’ is… ‘Alone together’ is literal nonsense.”</invalid_quote> (<quote>Testimony</quote>). He resorts to legalistic parsing only when his contemptuous denials no longer suffice.  
   • Immediately afterward he offers the partial apology: <invalid_quote>“Inappropriate was the nature of our actions… I regret the whole damn thing.”</invalid_quote> (<invalid_quote>Post‐Testimony Address</invalid_quote>). This admission marks a genuine exposure of self—vulnerability—before the public and under oath.  

4. Disbelief at his political survival  
   • In “The People Have Spoken,” he repeats thrice <quote> I can't believe what they had to say. </quote> (<quote>The People Have Spoken</quote>).  
   • He wonders how “I might be guilty of obstruction, yet my ratings are sky‐high… That must mean I'm a pretty good president, though how, I don't think I know.” (<quote>The People Have Spoken</quote>). His repeated “can't believe” and “I don’t think I know” express astonishment, not humility or contrition.  

Objections to “Surprise → Secrecy → Humility”

A. “Surprise” misreads his agency  
   • He actively brings in Monica (“We'll bring in an intern… I assure you… Your routine here won't get blown.”) (<quote>The Shutdown</quote>), and Monica “led him on” (<quote>What Went On</quote>). He does not sing “Oh!” in shock; he invites her.  

B. “Secrecy” is tactical, not emotional  
   • Denial is his response to contempt and is overtly combative, not fearful. Secrecy methods (legal traps, parsing definitions) emerge only after contempt fails; they reflect strategy, not the affective arc.  

C. “Humility” is absent or extremely limited  
   • His apology is grudging and immediately followed by claims of privacy interest (<quote> The country doesn't need to know these things. </quote>), reflecting self‐interest.  
   • He quickly returns to disbelief and rejoicing in survival in “The People Have Spoken,” rather than sustained contrition. True humility would not culminate in astonishment at own success.  

D. Chronology conflict  
   • Debater_B places humility at the end, but the text ends with disbelief and boasts of rating success, not renewed apologies. The final trio repeats disbelief and self‐praise, not humility.  

Conclusion  
Only “Loneliness → Contempt → Vulnerability → Disbelief” traces his emotional journey: from isolation, fighting back, forced exposure, to astonishment at his own retention of power. Debater_B’s labels conflate tactics with emotion, misplace chronology, and ignore the dominant lyrical emphasis on loneliness and disbelief.

1. REAFFIRMING “SURPRISE → SECRECY → HUMILITY” AS BILL’S TRUE AFFECTIVE ARC  
   
   A. Surprise at Monica’s Arrival and the Affair’s Allure  
     • The narrative’s inciting incident is Clinton’s encounter with the intern, not his “lonely” preamble. He immediately pivots: “tell the secretaries…we’ll bring in an intern” to preserve “routine”<quote>The Shutdown</quote>. His eagerness to have Monica “take him pizza!”<quote>President Lonely</quote> and the lurid “What Went On” number underscore genuine astonishment and titillation. This is the emotional catalyst driving the plot forward, not mere isolation.  
     • If “loneliness” were primary, why does he so quickly abandon loneliness for clandestine trysts? His impulse to “muddle through” only tracks his shock and hope that the intern will resolve his shutdown woes.  

   B. Secrecy as Dominant Emotional-State During Crisis  
     • Through four musical numbers Clinton obsesses over concealment: “I just can’t say a word right now” and “I never had sex with that woman”<quote>I Never Have</quote>; “Depends what the definition of ‘is’ is”<quote>Testimony</quote>. His every lyric rails at Starr for “wasting… public money” only to mask his guilt. This fear-and-anxiety state pervades all public actions.  
     • Debater A mislabels this as “contempt” or “vulnerability,” but contempt is a rationalized façade to legitimize secrecy; vulnerability doesn’t surface until he loses control and must swear under oath. Even then, he clings to legal hair-splitting (““alone together” is literal nonsense”<quote>Testimony</quote>) rather than open remorse.  

   C. Humility and Contrition as Final State  
     • At last, Clinton abandons stratagems in his post-testimony address: “Inappropriate was the nature of our actions, And believe me I regret the whole damn thing.”<quote>Testimony</quote>. This public apology—however grudging—marks the first genuine acceptance of wrongdoing.  
     • The concluding ensemble “The People Have Spoken” finds him no longer defiant: he expresses baffled gratitude (“I can’t believe…my ratings are sky-high”) but frames it as validation of his “better world” agenda rather than personal vindication. His acceptance of fate and return to governing displays restored humility and readiness to be judged on policy, not scandal.  

2. CRITIQUE OF “LONELINESS → CONTEMPT → VULNERABILITY → DISBELIEF”  
   
   A. Misplaced “Loneliness” as Start  
     • <quote>"President Lonely"</quote> is a musical interlude that dramatizes his official impotence during the shutdown; it ends the moment Monica arrives. It functions as exposition, not as sustained emotional journey. Every subsequent scene focuses on the affair, not on his solitude.  

   B. “Contempt” and “Vulnerability” Are Tactical, Not Enduring Emotions  
     • Clinton’s censure of Starr (“prosecutorial disgrace”) constitutes strategic deflection, a subset of secrecy, not genuine moral outrage. If he truly felt contempt, he would risk truth instead of doubling down on lies.  
     • His “vulnerability” appears only after Starr’s relentless tactics corner him; even then, his language remains legalistic and privacy-driven (“country doesn’t need to know”<quote>Testimony</quote>), indicating shame and fear, core components of humility’s emergence.  

   C. “Disbelief” at the End Is Merely Residual Surprise, Not Primary Conclusion  
     • His “I can’t believe” at the midterms reflects lingering astonishment, but he follows it by celebrating his agenda and abjuring further prosecution: “the removal threat is over…Kenneth Starr should go away”<quote>The People Have Spoken</quote>. This shows he has moved past shock into humble acceptance of public will. True disbelief would perpetuate denial, yet he ceases lying and resumes governance.  

3. AGAINST “SECRECY” AS “MERELY A MEANS”  
   • Emotional arcs in drama often hinge on fear and concealment as genuine psychological states. Clinton’s anxiety pervading every “I never” and “I just can’t say” lyric reveals deep internal conflict. Secrecy is not a neutral tactic but an anguished feeling he cannot shake until forced confession.  

4. TEXTUAL COHERENCE: THREE STAGES SURPASS FOUR  
   • Parsimony: “Surprise, Secrecy, Humility” captures all pivotal transitions with direct lyrical support. Debater A’s four-term model splinters overlapping feelings and double-counts surprise (“loneliness” & later “disbelief”).  
   • Dramatic unity: The show is framed as a musical comedy of errors driven by an unexpected intern, escalating through secretive farce, culminating in a contrite finale. Our triadic structure mirrors classical Acts I–III.  

Conclusion  
Only “Surprise → Secrecy → Humility” aligns with the narrative’s inciting incident, sustained conflict, and ultimate resolution. Debater A’s arc misreads exposition as sustained feeling, conflates tactical maneuvers with genuine emotion, and denies the play’s redemptive ending. Therefore, my answer best reflects Bill’s character journey from shock through concealed turmoil to genuine contrition.
